What I don't understand is the nattering on about which country piles up the largest collection of medals. Why do you care? The Olympics are not a world war to be fought every four years, or a giant test to see which country has the best coaching staff or sports regime. The skiers, snowboarders, skaters and bobsledders we've watched over the past days are magnificent individuals whose exploits should be honored for their own sakes, not for some country's standing in an international medal sweepstakes. Watch Lindsey Vonn and Maria Riesch, good friends from different countries who ski against each other but also together. My guess is that these athletes are like combat soldiers: They don't fight the war for country or party; they do it for the buddies that fight alongside them.

As I understand it, the expected value per 3 point shot last year was greater than that of a 2 point shot. A natural result should be that teams shoot more 3 point shots. Naturally, defenses will adjust. The optimal situation is such that the expected value for a 2 or 3 point shot are the same.

I often wonder how important a coach is relative to the players on a team. I would guess that win percentages might be altered as much as 10% a year based on a coach (ignoring wild and gross incompetence). Even though this is flawed, a relevant metric for judging a coaches ability might be something like wins after trailing. Making corrections based on the game flow is the mark of a good coach, not having the best players on the floor. Most of the "coaches of the year" are such because they win games, not because they are actually good coaches. For instance, how many times has Jerry Sloan won coach of the year?

Sorry Jay, but not only are you mixing metaphors but you're missing the point. In most countries athletes are funded by the government, so they actually ARE representing their countries coaching regimes. Even in the good ol' U S of A, sports like Nordic Combined - where the US won a medal in all three events, including the first ever for the US - were financed by the USOC, which is partially supported by tax dollars.

You seem to argue that soldiers also can somehow be separated from the government that sends them to fight and the people back home they're supposedly fighting for. Wha?? Whatever, frankly I think we should replace war with sports. If international disputes were settled by which team had the most Olympics medals the world would be a safer, healthier place.

Also, can we PLEASE stop nattering on about how the World Series is an inaccurate title? Look, the World Series was created and named by a newspaper in 1903. World Series was an exaggeration even back then, but not entirely wrong - the American and National Leagues were the only professional leagues in the world at the time (even though Cuba had club teams and hosted both negro leagues and white US pro teams). A series between the best teams in the only two pro baseball leagues in the world is, by definition, a world championship. The name doesn't change because its a recognisible brand.

thank you, Mr. Cassone, this letter comes straight to home. i have two sons in the military and one is now in Marjah. he is with 3/6 HS SVC and we just heard from him yesterday 25th for the first time in 5 weeks. each day that passes by is more emotionally draining from not hearing from him. but in my heart i know that he is there doing the job that he needs to do to get himself and the others back home once again with their families. for me there is a lot of support and much graditude from my place of employment. each day i have someone asking if i have heard anything from my son. i have both of my sons pictures in their uniforms hanging on the wall and not a day goes by that i hear a sempfer fi from some retired marine who just happened to come in. we sit together and talk about what my sons are doing and what they did when they were in the military. the days are mostly tolerable but the nights are excruciating. i wait to hear my marine come running in the door and taking two stairs at a time and yelling down to me i have to hurry what's for dinner when he comes home on leave. then within a few seconds with my back turned i have his arms wrapped around me telling me hi. those days are long and few between now, but i pray every night to bring them home. God Bless each and everyone, for he is the only one who knows the outcome.

The ISI still supports the insurgency in Afghanistan, and has repeatedly killed, captured, or threatened any taliban members who have tried to stop fighting.

INDIA BEING TARGETED IN AFGHANISTAN
By Brigadier Chitranjan Sawant,VSM
IT IS EARLY MORNING AROUND SIX OR SO on 26TH FEBRUARY 2010. Two suicide bombers are lurking into dark corners. One is headed for Safi hotel and the other for the posh place adjacent to it where high brows stay. Both the human bombers succeed in detonating their devices. As many as 18 persons, mostly foreigners including nine Indians at the last headcount lay dead. Unfortunately there are five Indian Army personnel among those killed and two are still missing. About 35 men including some Indians were injured. Arrangements are being made to evacuate the injured to India for proper medical attention and treatment. Sometime back also there was a bomb blast near the Indian Embassy in Kabul located at a stone throw distance from these two hotels. Fortunately none of the diplomats was killed or injured both the times, albeit the Indian Defence attaché and a career diplomat had lost their lives in another terrorist attack prior to that.
Every time an attack on Indian life and property takes place, it is the Taliban that takes responsibility for it. Is that Islamist Terrorist outfit alone? Are they so prepared as to mount an attack on the Indian interests in Kabul? No, they are not alone. The Pakistan establishment, especially the Army is backing them. There is a tape recorded conversation that took place between General Pervez Musharraf, then in Beijing on an annual pilgrimage to draw inspiration and military sustenance from the time-tested ally, China. And General Ashfak Pervez Kayani in Pakistan when the latter described the Islamist terror organisation as close supporters of the Pakistan Army who would protect the Army’s flanks when there is a war with India. Various terror organisations in Pakistan are fed, nourished and armed to teeth by the Pakistan Army and the front organisation to do so is the ISI. As a matter of fact, they are all chips of the same block. If any one does hair splitting and differentiates one from the other as a State actor or a non-State actor, he or she is only fooling self and deluding a sworn enemy.
AMERICAN WITHDRAWAL AND THEREAFTER
President Obama and his administration have made up their mind that an organised withdrawal of the US forces and NATO allies should begin in or around July 2011. The American coming into Afghanistan in 2001 was a great success because both the Al Qaida and the Taliban disappeared from that country. Pakistan had been ruling Afghanistan through the terrorist outfits. In fact the Taliban was born of and brought up by the Pakistan Army. However, in a master stroke of diplomacy, General Musharaff chose to support the Americans to the hilt and, of course, take its pound of flesh. America poured in money, material and munitions of war into Pakistan to have a Muslim country on its side while waging war against Islamist terror outfits. Pakistan was with America outwardly and did capture some terror leaders to please the USA but its real sights were on India as a potential enemy. The aim plus was to govern Afghanistan as and when an opportunity came.
The whole world knows that the United States is very powerful in air warfare and its navy is a mighty force ruling waves like Britannia did in the last century. But on land the American GIs are poor fighters. The comfortable life style an American citizen is used to, precludes him from a trench warfare. Be it Korea in early 1950s, Vietnam in 1960s or for that matter the Second World War, the American infantry did not acquit itself well. Infantry is known as the Queen of battle. Here the queen reigns and rules and holds the ground. The American infantry did not win laurels in the close quarter battle. They did not excel in aggressive patrolling or smashing terror outfits in Afghanistan. Even after the great surge when the Obama ordered 30,000 additional troops to be deployed in Afghanistan, the President who iis also the Commander-in-Chief of all US forces was not sure of the outcome.
President Obama called his new strategy as SURGE AND QUIT. In any case the American or the European troops are not deployed permanently in Afghanistan. They should achieve the aim of establishing law and order, train the Afghan National Army and the Police and thereafter return home. In a way it can be termed as a sound decision. The snail speed of the elite US Marines in moving towards Marjah, the Taliban stronghold, and capturing it for the sake of flag hoisting by the Afghan Mayor does not inspire confidence among the rank and file of the NATO forces. The Afghan Mayor, a returnee from Germany, is in position but the Taliban sniper fire in Marjah goes on unabated. The Islamist terrorist in Marjah may be down but they are not out.
INDIA SIDELINED BY PAKISTAN
My heart bleeds for my country. After the Soviet withdrawal, our presence there became untenable. The then President of Afghanistan, looked towards India but in vain.

Trust is a binding force that cements human relationship. Its waning hold is likely to put rhythm at risk between two individuals, communities or nations.

Numerous instances in record witness to the gory incidents of violence out of the fall of mutual trust. The slightest happening even at a very personal level between two divergent individuals flares up into a cauldron resulting into uneasy calm and communal tension.

The recent mass shooting by Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan on Nov. 5, 2009 at Fort Hood that cost thirteen valuable lives is a grim reminder of what might happen to the community he belongs to in an atmosphere of congenial mistrust.

Though the incident should be termed like any other isolated case caused by a disturbed army officer, and some have argued to the point, yet by and large media as well as the public including the establishment look at it with skepticism and suspicion. The loyalty of entire American Muslim community is under scanner ignoring allegiance of approximately ten thousand Muslim army officers to the nation.

Cynical and contemptuous follow-up headlines stigmatizing a particular community for the tragedy hit across the globe and the American media too. ‘U.S. Knew of Suspect’s Tie to Radical Cleric’, ‘Complications Grow for Muslims Serving in U.S. Military’, ‘Army Chief Concerned for Muslim Troops’ were some of them by The New York Times that drew undue attention of public to the ensuing misfortune.

The shooting spree in America is not new. Out of distress, unable to cope with emerging pressures in life, individuals in the past have pulled the trigger to fatal outcome.

To single out Fort Hood carnage and to correlate it to Islam, as the perpetrator happens to be a Muslim and possibly a regular visitor to mosque, are not only premature but also lacking in the mindset of investigation.

Innumerable cases of deviant behavior by the combatants in action back home have worried the experts and have resulted into countless unwarranted incidents.

While other incidents caused by identical behavioral disorder were not viewed in terms of one’s faith, Hasan’s has sparked off a debate.

Once again Islam is in the centre of discussion. The fact that America is at war with two Muslim nations, Iraq and Afghanistan, more a doing of political fallout, does not imply that Islam is against values America stands for.

The link to Islam is fast established for any misfortune that befalls but the other way round is hardly possible. How many of us know about devoted Muslim American soldiers laying their lives for the nation?

Holding Islam to ransom habitually is the weakest hypothesis we generate eclipsing in the process the real cause of conflict that may be psychological, social, economic or political. It is time to depart from the custom.
